posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69785435
The biggest bit of info I can give you is do it how it won't injure you. That is vague but it's true. You decide your grip, you decide your hand width, you decide how low you bring the bar down based on your arm length. This lift, more than any other, depends on your build. It's very easy to fuck your shoulders up watching some video of some dick fart telling you it has to be this or that. Doing it completely strict with no back bend is a for sure ticket to fucking up your shoulder and/or using tiny amounts of weight. Also the only good cue I can give you is think of it as an arm movement not a shoulder movement. Save your shoulders anon, the human shoulder is easily fucked up so squeezing the bar hard and using your arms to drive it up will keep you going a lot longer than people you see with a wimpy grip and shoulder fucking it upwards. Don't worry about muh strict press, muh proper blah blah, you're not competing in an ohp contest, nobody is.

NTA, but you're the one acting like a retarded mongoloid. Vegetable oil in the context of food is always used as a catchall for neutral tasting oils made up of poly unsaturated fatty acids derived from seeds. They are all high in omega 6. Plants produce them in such small amounts that hundreds to thousands of seeds are required to produce a single tablespoon. The production process requires dissolution in hexane, a known poison, bleaching and artificial deodorizing, so the finished product is about as natural as plastic. Soi, rapeseed (AKA canola), cottonseed, or any other plant seed based oil is similarly processed. Widespread adoption of seed oils in the 20th century coincides with the rise of heart disease, diabetes, and obesity and the highly processed goyslop that is universally agreed to be terrible for health (eg: fried fast food, packaged snack cakes, frozen pastas/pizzas) universally contains seed oils. Anyone shilling for this trash is the modern day equivalent of the doctors that used to endorse cigarette brands.

Olive oil is much higher in omega 3 fatty acids. It can be squeezed directly from the fruit of the tree and has been consumed by humans for thousands of years. The Mediterranean Diet, which is often cited by vegan shills as evidence that plant fats are healthier than animal fats, contains high amounts of olive oil and ZERO seed oils.

Protips from someone in the same boat
>read inspirational works, especially biblical stuff
>go to the gym, it really does help knowing the time was constructive instead of self-loathing. Even doing a set of pushups is helpful if you can
>get some kind of creative outlet or project. Even if you're doodling a cartoon character with some pencil or building a house in minecraft, just MAKE something that's yours
>talk to people, doesn't even have to be about your suffering just chat, unload and get your mind off of it for a while
>have self awareness and be introspective, be willing to answer the hard questions about yourself
>stop worrying so much and try to enjoy the existence you have, the world isn't owed any "proper" version of you that makes a load of money or is popular. Being good to yourself and the people around you is much better than what most of the world is doing anyway
>you aren't weak for your internal suffering, you're strong for enduring it and not succumbing
I write this while in abject misery myself, but fuck it I might as well keep going. Things have been worse before, and they can be better later.

I don't get why people (mainly americans) get so irrationally mad at the idea of someone using a mode of transport other than a car in a city. American city architecture forcing everyone to drive to get anything done at all is the reason their cities are so shit. Yes, have a car, drive it to get places when you need to, but every time someone doesnt drive one, theyre not contributing to the dogshit air quality, high level of noise, and traffic congestion that make living in cities so bad. And as for cyclists obstructing traffic or whatever, if 75% of space is reserved for cars with fuckhuge parking lots and roads everywhere, just give the bikers 5%. Adding another lane doesnt noticeably reduce congestion anyway due to induced demand, whereas every person choosing to use a bike instead actually does. Also, the concept of suburbs and american city planning in general is garbage and QoL in a city does not have to be that bad. Its better than raising children in some crime ridden city center, but its still terrible because due to the terrible intentional design decisions, they are prevented from going anywhere or doing anything without a car, and driving a bike along the large roads connecting suburbs to everything else is hilariously dangerous.
I understand that americans dont comprehend that it doesnt have to be like that because its all they know, and I understand that cyclists can be annoying if they disregard their own safety and do stupid shit. But you still look retarded aping out like an actual nigger about how youre gonna run them over or whatever.

>>69789933
People executed by guillotine have been seen moving their lips as well as responding to stimuli:

>In 1905, a French physician sought to find out. He attended an execution and stood close to the guillotine. He approached as soon as the severed head tumbled into the basket below and called out the man’s name. He claimed the eyelids lifted and the man looked briefly at him before lowering his gaze. The physician called his name again and received a similar response. The man did not respond to a third prompt. The physician concluded based on his observations that a severed head could retain consciousness for 25 to 30 seconds.

Whether this is intentional movement or merely just muscle twitching from random nerve synapses firing is unknown (and may likely never be known).

There are reports of people who have had heart attacks being able to relate things that were said or happened in between flatlining and being resuscitated, so it's clear that the brain is still able to function and interpret data, at least for a short period of time, even with a complete loss in blood pressure, relying solely on the oxygen it has absorbed from blood immediately before the event. There has also been evidence of delta waves spreading through the brain up to 30 minutes after cardiac failure.

tl;dr - There is a chance that the guy may have had the split second of panic as he realized he was about to be run over, then been consciously aware of his head shooting across the sidewalk and rolling to a stop.

This is also why on the rare instances I do ride a bike I ride on the sidewalk. I would rather have to ride around someone occasionally or risk getting a $10 ticket than risk my body being turned into hamburger because some retard in a car wasn't paying attention.

Previous: >>69745682

>Advice for new runners
- Build up speed and mileage SLOOOOWLY (start with 15 minutes, increase time/mileage by 10% per week)
- Yes, it will feel like you're going slow, you are; don't worry about setting good times for at least a couple months
- If you start to feel pain anywhere, stop and rest, then run a shorter distance next time or walk
- Don't worry about form, the human body knows how to run, just do what comes naturally
- Once you can comfortably run 6 miles/10km, start thinking about a goal in terms of race distance and time, and look for a training plan for that goal (see below for suggested plans)

>Couch to 5k Guide
https://www.nhs.uk/live-well/exercise/running-and-aerobic-exercises/get-running-with-couch-to-5k/
>Sprinters Guides
https://trackstarusa.com/
>I want to run a fast 5k, 10k, half-marathon, or marathon
https://www.runningfastr.com/ (with goal times)
https://www.halhigdon.com/ (more planning necessary but more thorough workouts/explanations)
>Stretching guide
https://www.runnersworld.com/uk/training/beginners/a32172701/how-to-stretch-post-run/
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OIXVDdH3o6g

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I've been running consistently for 3 months now and I'm thinking of adding in tempo runs or hill repeats to my schedule. How often should I do these? Is once a week enough to see benefits?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69774058
Should be fine. Introduce gradually - shortish tempo run or short hill session to begin with. You could do hills and tempos on alternate weeks.
Hills can be done as a series of efforts up a long hill with a walk or jog back (almost like a track session), or a continuous effort on a shorter hill (5, 10, 15 etc minutes) working on the uphill and "freewheeling" down, giving a bit of recovery.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69774257
There's a long hill about a mile from my house. My plan was easy run to the hill for warm up, run up and down the hill several times, then run back.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69774388
Warm up (and down) a good idea. If it is a long hill then maybe run up and down halfway to start and increase as you feel stronger. Caution generally pays off.

posts.com: I had an ankle injury and I had to stop running. It's been abit wore than a year and my ankle is fully healed. I used to run 10k in 45 min 2-3 times a week. What's the best way to get back ? I'm swimming a lot now, so I still have a good breathing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: just started running, 200lbs managed to get to 3 miles in 25 minutes but getting past 3-4 miles is just pure pain. is this normal for everyone ?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69778681
>I had an ankle injury and I had to stop running. It's been abit wore than a year and my ankle is fully healed.
Same (Broken ankle, repaired with pins and plates.) It took a year to get back to being able to run at all and another year to be able to move at any kind of pace.

My advice is to go very slow in coming back and be conscious of what you're doing because there are all sorts of stabilizer muscles that have atrophied and will get sore. Plus, when you run, you'll be so self-conscious about protecting the ankle that you'll mess up your stride and end up hurting something else. (In my case, it was the opposite side hip)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69778580

If you have trouble gauging effort and pace, yes. If you want to base training on heart rate rather than perceived effort, yes. If you want to geek out comparing sessions, yes. If you are worried about being tracked, probably not - most have GPS and will upload session data to wherever.

I am only familiar with Polar watches & sensors and have always found them to be reliable. Battery life seems a PITA with all of the smart watches.

Polar also offer 'smart' training plans for various distances - haven't tried these. I imagine the other manufacturers have their own versions.

>>69786773
>What's the difference between repeats and intervals?
(In American terminology) Repeats are usually an on-track exercise. You run a set distance, say 800m, at a set pace then take a lap to cool down. Jogging or even walking. Then you perform a set number of those 800m runs. When people talk about 4x800s, they say they ran 800m 4 times.

Intervals are an exercise where you vary your speed while on a long run. Over the course of a 10-mile run, you can do intervals by running 100m fast ever 2 miles, or you can switch up running 1 mile at easy pace and 1 mile at race pace and then another at easy pace. With intervals you don't stop to cool down as dramatically as repeats, nor do you run as fast.

>>69780289
Broadly, it's not bullshit. For the most part it's accurate assuming you're interpreting "overweight" and "obese" as measurements of overall health, which you should.

The problem arises when you're high BMI but also high muscle. If you're 6'2 230 you're in the "overweight" category. If you're built like an NFL linebacker and low BF%, high in muscle (assuming you're natty) are you really "unhealthy" or overweight/obese? Most likely not. At the same time you could be 6'2, 170 lbs and in the normal weight range but you're a skinny-fat dyel with absolutely ZERO muscle on his body and a layer of pudge covering everything with a shit diet and being generally unhealthy.

Still, it's accurate and correct in probably 95% of cases. Most people who pretend they shouldn't be categorized as overweight are indeed overweight. They might be fairly athletic, they might be fairly muscular, they're almost certainly fat enough to be unhealthy. Railing against BMI is a massive cope for fat fucks who want to pretend that they should be considered healthy before actually becoming healthy. How about you cut, remove all that fat, and then we'll talk? If your BMI is still overweight and you're low BF then you won't even CARE what some BMI number says about you because it'll be so obvious and self-evident that you're still healthy that you don't seek validation in some kind of bs number.

>The limitation of the BMI to classify subjects has been largely described in literature.
>A higher proportion of muscle mass overestimates BMI. Subjects who are rela-tively disproportionate between upper and lower body parts usually have their BMI underestimated. In our sample, the sensitivity of the BMI was 91.9%, which means that 90% of the normal weight people were classified as normal. The specificity was only 48.4%, which means that 50% of the overweight individuals were classified as overweight.
>There are two possibilities to limit FN: using an additional method to evaluate BF% or using a higher cutoff for the BMI. In our sample, 29 candidates were classified as FN. It is important to note that 23 individuals (80%) of the 29 classified as FN had a BMI between 25.0 kg/m2 and 27.0 kg/m2.
>Adding an impedance measurement for the BMI category at 25.0 kg/m2 to 27.0 kg/m2 would classify these candidates correctly. A second approach would be using a higher BMI cutoff: with a cutoff of 27.0 kg/m2, FN would decrease to 6.
>However, the number of FP would increase compared with a BMI cutoff of 25.0 kg/m2, from 47 to 68. A problem with this second approach is that using a higher cutoff of 27.0 kg/m2 would select a different sample, probably with the same problems as FN.
>From this study, we can conclude that the BMI method, combined with impedance, classified 83% of the volunteers correctly: 372 of the 448 were correctly classified with both methods as normal or overweight. This criterion is also technically easy to use. Because of the high number of candidates each year for a military career, using a systematic bioelectrical impedance measurement is too time-consuming. However, a BMI between 25.0 kg/m 2 and 27.0 kg/m 2 does not indicate that an individual is over-fat.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>69786719
nta

>As for the PCT, isnt it advised to come off
current wisdom is that the hormonal rollercoaster of PCT is less healthy than just dropping down to cruise dosages
assuming ofc you plan to cycle again

>or could I just cruise 250mg until my next blast?
in theory, a cruise should be basically like TRT, it should put you within the physiological range
the idea being that with natural test levels your body will recover from any damage done to it from blasting. or at least, high test levels will no longer be causing damage, nor would you need to use AI or other ancillaries
250mg would almost certainly be more than that, unless you're extremely huge already. ofc you should check with bloods
mind you, that doesn't necessarily mean that 250mg would be unhealthy or that it would prevent you from recovering or anything
just that its not what "cruise" really means, and that its not known/guaranteed to be healthy long term
tldr imo cruise at whatever dosage gets you to high natty test levels, just to be on the safe side

>>69785939
assume that it takes 150mg/wk to replace natty test levels

250mg/wk = 100mg/wk surplus * 32 = 3200mg surplus

500mg/wk = 350mg/wk surplus * 16 = 5600mg surplus

so no, you can't just do half the dose for twice as long and get the same results.

however, the dose-response relationship holds true so the same "total" dose should result in the same "total" gains, within reason. but if you're going to do 2000mg/wk you need to eat like you're doing 2000mg/wk and train like you're doing 2000mg/wk, and most people can't do that. which is why it makes sense to do less for longer. but eating and training enough to justify 500mg/wk or even 1000mg/wk is definitely achievable for most people.

posts.sub: Why do some people look super strong, and are not or the reverse?
posts.com:
I'm wondering if anyone else has ever experienced this, but today we had a guy visit our gym, white belt who happens to be a personal trainer. This guy is super ripped, like 6 pack abs, and everything. Eventually we get around to rolling, and I roll with this guy, and I feel nothing that I'd expect from his physique. His muscles feel like anybody else's body, he doesn't feel strong at all, even though aesthetically, he would appear to be so. I could even muscle out of bad positions successfully against him.

In contrast, when I roll with my coach, (who's like a 5'6, unassuming guy, doesn't even look in shape), touching him feels like touching stone. Even when he's relaxed you can just feel that he's super muscle bound. You would think that he's flexing all the time, but the man is actually just like that. My coach says he only lifts weights like once or twice a week, meanwhile the other guy literally lives and breathes the gym, yet feels like any other random person.

Has anybody else ever had a similar experience? Does anyone have an idea on why there is such a disparity between the two? My coach has maybe a decade and a half of age on this guy (mid 20s vs early 40s), is it the fabled old man strength? Does rolling bjj day in day out really get you that strong in comparison to the average (or even gym going) individual? I'm genuinely so confused right now.

>>69789672
It's not that simple. First of all finasteride doesn't even block all of the DHT, so depending on the individual, they may continue to grow body hair and facial hair at a normal rate, and even on dutasteride, you're leaving out the fact that plain old testosterone is still highly androgenic, and will still cause further masculinization and hair growth, and potentially hair LOSS, even if there is not DHT present.
And lets say some day you do want a beard and finasteride is stopping that? Fine, stop taking finasteride. You haven't permanently stunted your beard growth by taking finasteride, hell you haven't even "pressed the pause button" so to speak, you've dammed up a river, and when you open the flood gates, you're going to get really really hair, and really really bald, within the span of a year or two. Your body tends to play "catch up" when you discontinue finasteride, so it's not even like you are delaying having your precious beard, you will be exactly where you would have been had you never touched the drug.

>Incidence and type of adverse events, and cause of discontinuation, did not differ meaningfully between topical finasteride and placebo. No serious adverse events were treatment related. posts.com:
once you get into fitness, you both improve and ruin your life at the same time.
being lean, mobile, strong and overall healthy is a blessing. the bar to be considered muscular to the general populace is so low it actually doesn't take much to be considered jacked.
on the flip side, fitness is a lifelong commitment. you start to notice things about your body you never did before and you obssess over small minute things. most people, although they won't admit it, will develop some form of body dysmorphia.
your relationship with food might also never be the same. food becomes numbers and you start to feel bad when you deviate from your diet.

in the end, to me, both lethargy and fitness cause pain and unease in their own ways. but i'd pick the path of fitness every single time

>>69790580
Yeah, you're right anon.
Here is a study where rats were fed concentrated potato protein. The potato-proteinase inhibitor concentration (PPIC) group had an 11.6% lower weight gain compared to a control group!
Let's look at the numbers.
The rats were fed PPIC at doses 100mg / 1kg bodyweight. A rule of thumb is to divide a rat dose by 6.2 to get a human dose. So a 75kg man would require around 16mg / 1 kg of PPIC to expect similar effects on weight gain. 16*75 = 1200mg
1 gram of potato yielded around 0.25mg of PPIC. So to get a 1200mg dose for a 75kg man, you would require [grams of potato] = [1200/0.25]
1200/0.25 = 4800
4800grams or 4.8kg of potatoes, every day.

Yeah, I don't think you have to worry about protease inhibitors in your tubers, anon. They have evolved in plants in response to infection by fungi and browsing by insects. They do not exist in concentrations large enough to have noticeable effects on humans.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>69790959
I'm making the best inferences I can with available data. Tubers don't make people fat, that's a typically simplistic carnivore/keto talking point that ignores total caloric intake, macronutrient profile and activity levels.
The burden of proof is on you to demonstrate that protease inhibitors, at levels typically encountered in the diet, have demonstrable effects.
The fact is that even when amplified in concentration thousands of times, their effects are slight, and not universally deleterious - The PPIC rats in the present study had lower food intake (which explains their reduced weight gain, rather than some protein malabsorption), delayed gastric emptying, lower plasma insulin whilst serum glucose remained unchanged, demonstrating lower insulin resistance than the control-group rats.

posts.com:
>>69781941
This is the best take. Most people drink coffee, some to excess, and handle it more or less fine. Anxious people, on the other hand, can have one coffee and be a complete wreck.
Our level of alertness is subjective. If I’m normally not very stimulated, then caffeine brings me up to a place of pretty average stimulation. But the difference feels like getting high and becoming uber-productive and energetic. By contrast, someone who is wound very tight drinks caffeine and their stimulation level crosses the line into anxiety. The caffeine didn’t do more to them than it did to the first person, they were just starting from different places.
Think about it like lifting. Lifting by itself is relatively safe. But your risk of injury is significantly higher if you’re out of shape and you haven’t stretched. That doesn’t mean lifting is risky, it means that certain people are prone to injury.
I say all this because I cannot drink caffeine, I get panic attacks. But I had anxiety before I ever touched the stuff and I still have it now years since I last touched it.

>>69789139
Congrats OP!

I was in your position roughly 6 months ago (75*5*5). Did madcow and stalled at a 3RM of 90 Restarted madcow, stalled immediately. Friends recommended smolov jr so i tried it. 4 weeks later hit 5RM of 95 kg, and 1RM of 100.

I think i had 2,5-5 kg more in me for a 1RM, but I was already gassed from hitting 5s at 95, 92,5 and 90, don't know why I did that.

Anyways, if you eventually do Smolov Jr. be careful. I had periods of moderate pain in shoulders and elbows, it's alot of volume so thats to be expected. But again, be careful. Its also gonna take alot of time out of your day. My 10x3 on week 3 was 90 kg and knocked me the fuck out for the rest of the day. I would also recommend doing the saturday set on Sunday so that the heavy and light day are next to eachother.

The good thing about doing Smolov is that it got me used to benching, the weights on week 1 were so light that i could focus alot on form. You will also get used to lower reps which will help you with your 1RM.

posts.sub: Why are normies so completely delusional about starvation?
posts.com:
My gf had been wanting to watch pic related with me (she's a zoomer girl who's seven years younger than me and legitimately hadn't seen it yet - neither had I because I try to avoid such "muh female empowerment" fantasies) for a long time and yesterday I finally did her the favor after she had been pestering me for months about it.

In general, it wasn't as bad as I had suspected, some parts were even somewhat enjoyable, but while watching that movie, I couldn't help but notice that the people who wrote it are completely delusional about the effects of starvation.

Like, the movie is about a competition that's going to last two or three weeks tops. How on earth would food play any major role in such an event? A healthy human being - one who, according to the movie, has been overstuffed with delicacies for weeks before the competition itself begins - can survive at least double that time with zero food and continue to pretty much function as normal. I fast every year from carnival to easter (though admittedly taking minerals and vitamin supplements), that's 40 (!) days and I still can function normally and even lift weights.

Yet this movie tries to pretend that food is THE core aspect of that competition, that anyone who doesn't have access to food will inevitably die etc.

And this isn't the only movie/book/video game/whatever which does that weird shit. You oftentimes see fictional situations that go like: "Oh no, we've run out of food and the next place to get food is four days away, we will surely perish from starvation!"

Do normies genuinely think that you will just drop dead after a few days of eating nothing?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69790175
First of all, stop doing more than 45 minutes of cardio per day, and stop doing more than 2 hours of cardio per week.

Then stop using bitch ass weight.

What you can do is clean and press, cleaning between each presses. Though that's more upper-body focused; so alternatively you can replace the press with a push press, which is a little more technical, or a jerk, which is actually somewhat technical.
Technical means you'll fuck up if you're dumb.

Then there's dead snatches; only do those one-sided, because fuck having two separate weights overhead. Also obliques gains.

If you feel your legs are lacking do front squats (i.e. you hold the dumbbells, none of that bodyweight shit that doesn't work your abs).
Or even thrusters if you're a crossfit retard, which you might be given how much useless shit such as 7 hours of cardio per week you're doing.

Lift 3 days per week: lifting only destroys muscle, it's rest that builds them.

Do 2 or 3 sets, anything more has diminishing returns.
Once you can do more than 8 reps increase the weight.

Given how weak you sound, it's a safe estimate to say that you will not be able to handle 20kg for your first two years, but a pair of 10kg and 15kg will serve you well enough. Or get a single adjustable one and do everything one-sided. Only the front squat will lag a little behind, but that's not a big deal, you need to get going first before you worry about shit like that.
Unless you're old; old people have weak legs. Just do uphill sprints then.

>>69783061
>don’t eat equals hungry
>eat a shitload of carbs a day to not be hungry
That’s not how it works. When you’re fasting your ghrelin (hunger hormone) spikes during normal mealtimes and dies off after the first day, so the first day of a fast is the hardest and specifically lunchtime and dinnertime that first day.
If you eat a kilo of veg a day then you’re going to fuck yourself over with hunger cues too. Your body preferentially burns glucose over fat because glucose can’t be stored long term. When your glucose starts to run out your body produces ghrelin, making you hungry before you’ve even started burning your stored fat which is the goal.
And if you mean that you’re going to eat a kilo of spinach or something a day then all you’re going to get is massive diarrhea.

Cutting and calisthenics + cardio mostly. Cutting and eating healthy food is obvious, and I did a half hour power walk 5 days per week for cardio, and a half hour targeted calisthenics routine 6 days per week; 2 leg days, 2 core days, 2 upper body/arm days (one of the arm days is on a day I don’t do cardio). The upper body days are the ones I lift on, but for my physique I literally just do beginner lifts and if I’m feeling lazy I’ll just use dumbbells for the stuff that isn’t calisthenics. This is it. If you fuckers are either starting late to your New Years resolutions, or have failed and are looking to start over, the second best month is Feb. I invite you to join me on a 60 complete dopamine detox/monk-mode, whatever you personally wanna call it. It is my personal belief that if you can survive this challenge, then your life will have drastically changed for the better, even though it is a relatively short amount of time

>What is it?
This is a 60 day period where you totally remove yourself from the world and focus exclusively on internal development of both the physical and mental self. It is complete immersion.

These are my personal rules, feel free to modify these to fit your personal vices, challenges, and personalities;
>No Fapping or Porn
>No Alcohol/weed
>No TV or vidya
>No 5 chinz (or any social media)
>No algorithmic YouTube surfing (educational videos are allowed IF and ONLY if for school)
>No sugar/junk food
>No music outside of lifting
>Up before 8:00 AM every day

>Why would I want to do this? Who is this for?
This challenge is designed for any of you who just aren't where you want to be at in life. From giga NEETs, to students or professionals looking to get a competitive edge. No matter what walk of life you come from, you have nowhere to go but up by cutting ties with worldly distractions. If you are fully 100% content with where you're at in life, or are otherwise making good progress, feel free to skip this if you want, but you're invited to try it anyways.


1/2

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>What does this even do?
Frees up and increases natural levels of the molecule dopamine, the "go-getter molecule" in the brain, and makes your receptors more sensitive to weaker, but more wholesome dopamine releases. This translates to enjoying the little things in life more, to caring more about lifting, to wanting to study harder, and to completing any task that isn't the usual high stimuli/low reward. With increased dopamine comes better mood, outlook on life, competitiveness, and a much greater enjoyment of social interactions. 1/2
>What about SEX?
This one is a controversial subject, but it is fine to plow your gf during a dopamine detox in my opinion. There are many who believe that the oxytocin released during sex with someone you love counteracts the harmful effects of dopamine and prolactin release in the brain that comes with any orgasm. It should also be obvious, but if you're single, you will be burning absolute holes in women's skulls with your eye-contact, and your newfound masculinity makes it virtually inevitable that a woman will service your parts at some point. Whether you want to hunt for PAWGs, or fully retain your nut is up to you. Keep in mind that many within the monk-mode community particularly consider it out of bounds to have any sex whatsoever however.
>So what the fuck am I even allowed to do?

>read
>write
>School work
>journal
>lift
>meditate
>Go on nature walks
>Go talk to people or pickup chicks
>meal prep
>play an instrument
Remember - dopamine isn't your enemy. You're just trying to rewire your brain's risk/reward centers to an environment that makes you a hypermotivated chad who cannot stop hunting for success. I start Feb 1, join me

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Depends on your split.
>full body
If you can train your whole body every day and still recover, you are simply not training hard enough. Simple as.
>upper-lower
There are muscles in my body that simply can't seem to recover in two days. You could try doing cardio every third day but since cardio is almost always quite taxing on the legs I've found that I end up overtraining them all the same.
>PPL
It takes me about two weeks of alternating PPL workouts until I feel the need for a rest day. Even then, a good cardio session is fine because the strength routine is not as heavily skewed towards legs in the first place. To be on the safe side, I usually do strength six days a week (PPLPPL) and then have do just abs and cardio on the sixth day regardless.
>Bro split
Never seriously tried it but I'm doubtful it would work well. Having a dedicated arms day simply means that anything upper body the day right after would be a shit workout.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I hate these overcompensating lifters for manipulating young guys into muscle training when what they should be prioritising their cardiovascular and longterm health and ensuring they don’t get diabetes, heart disease, or the myriad of other conditions that come with normal weight obesity. Yes, the medical term for ‘skinnyfat’ is normal weight obesity—do you think these people would get away with advising a ‘bulk’ to an obese person?

While you will look like a skeleton at the end of your ‘cut’ you will at least be healthy and able to gain muscle from a good baseline. Otherwise, you will look like a bloated, overweight monster for years and you will lose half of your gains when you invariably ‘cut’. Your face will also lean out, and face is everything.

You’ll also notice that most of these bodybuilding programs are completely unrealistic for skinny fat people. They expect you to be able to do pull-ups and chin-ups even though you find it hard to do a single push-up. I would advise that after cutting you pursue calisthenics and get used to your body before pursuing weight training.

Please, just take 2 months to shed at least 15 pounds and do at least 2 hours of cardio everyday—there is no point in gaining muscle if you run out of breath after climbing a flight of stairs. You’ve neglected fitness and building endurance your entire life and you need to remedy that immediately. Then you can actually start doing stuff like swimming and hiking which will make life so much more enjoyable.

You will feel more confident skinny as you’ve probably always been overweight, and you will be motivated to improve your physique through lean bulks. Do not fall for the plots and machinations of strongmen and bodybuilders who want everyone to be as miserable as they are.

posts.sub: Where can I get some easy to make and tasty food for bodybuilding?
posts.com: Drop your recipe here or link me recipes. I want to eat for muscle building but most of my meals are bland and poorly tasting.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69788797
Eye of Round
season to taste, I use a marinade of olive oil, lime or lemon juice (whichever is on hand), salt, black pepper, cummin, chili powder, and paprika typically
put in the oven for 75 minutes at 400 or until 160~ internal, it should be pink
you'll be using it for stir fry
>rice noodles or white rice
>jalapenos (optional)
>red peppers
>bean sprouts
>green onions
>egg
>sricacha
cut the peppers and meat into thin strips and cook them in a skillet with olive oil until both start to brown
mix in the rice or rice noodles
add sricacha and stir
push the mix to one side and add the egg
scramble this off by itself and then mix in with rest once its cooked to satisfaction
lower heat
add in bean sprouts and green onions mix it a little bit more to get everything evenly spread
done
obviously ratios of beef to rice/noodles will be based on your desired macro

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69788797
>easy to make
Rice, either jasmine or calrose. Get a rice cooker with a keep warm function.
Lean ground meat, Shoot for 94+% lean. You can get 95 5 ground pork really inexpensively.
If you get a stovetop griddle you can pseudo grill chicken/certain cuts of beef en masse.
>tasty
arguably subjective, but buy and use spices. Eat your vegetables, etc. A good meal example follows:

170g of cooked chicken tender seasoned with Trader Joe's chile lime powder before cooking
200g of cooked jasmine rice
Everything but the bagel seasoning
1/4 a bell pepper diced
30g of fat free cheese
A spoonful of fat free sour cream
A spoonful of pico de gallo

Another example for multiple meals throughout the day would be
20oz of 95 5 ground pork (raw weight, also an entire package)
1/2 a package of some form of pasta (idgaf pick one)
1/2 a jar of relatively low fat pasta sauce
1 onion, 1 whole garlic. Whatever fucking vegetables you want to add (eg eggplant)
Boil the pasta in a sauce pan, fill with water slightly over the level of the pasta
In the other saucepan cook the package of ground meat
As both cook start to prepare the vegetables
As the pasta gets close to being done transfer the meat, vegetables and pasta sauce into the pasta pan and allow it to continue to cook until desired doneness or sauce consistency is achieved. Then portion it out into three meals. Add whatever seasonings you want to the meat you're an adult.

>>69759871
>rep ranges like 3x10 are not particularly good for hypertrophy because of sandbagging, rep ranges like 3x8-12 are much better. however, the fewer sets you do, the less flawed static rep ranges are, for example there is no sandbagging at all with 1x5, but 5x5 will result in a lot of sandbagging
What does sandbagging mean in this context?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69762526
Gn bro
>>69762572
>I'd like to add either hammer curls or finger curls, which one would be better in your opinion?
Probably finger curls for now since you're already doing reverse curls, however hammer curls are very easy to program in your training so you could figure out a slot for them once you've had the finger curls in for a while.
>>69762613
Not using your full effort, in this case you cannot go to failure (or even 1-2 RIR in some cases) on the first set because you wouldn't be able to hit the same amount of reps on the later sets due to fatigue, so you have to stop multiple reps from failure on the first set to prevent that from happening, which isn't what you want. Even if you don't intend on going to failure anyway this still causes the intensity on each set to be different as the later sets will be closer to failure than the earlier ones, while with a rep range you can keep the amount of reps in reserve about the same on each set.

Now, sandbagging isn't inherently bad if you're doing it intentionally, but static rep ranges force you to unintentionally sandbag, which is obviously bad.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69766009
>Please redpill on the rows causing hernias meme
Assuming you're talking about barbell rows, it's definitely a meme. Now the chance of injuring your back doing cheat rows instead of normal bb rows is definitely higher, but cheat rows aren't worth it IMO due to the fatigue cost (+ tracking progression is annoying). If you do much stricter BB rows (no using the lower back or hips to move the weight, controlled eccentric, and performed off of a deficit ideally. Also higher rep range) the chances of a back injury are pretty much nonexistent, so if you're scared of injuring your back you should do those instead. And for extra insurance, do your back extensions and RDLs for strong erectors, and optionally jefferson curls so that your spine becomes acclimated to flexion under load. Those should reduce the injury risk even further.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69766009
Also forgot to mention, if you're talking about db rows then I'm not too sure as I don't do them personally but I know some people use a staggered stance instead of one knee on a bench for that reason. But idk how much it really matters desu, only way I can see someone getting a hernia doing that is if they're egolifting and using a ton of spinal rotation to move the weight instead of actually using their back muscles. Just don't egolift, and if you want to be extra sure use a staggered stance instead of one leg on the bench.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>69767882
>I rarely focus on my upper body due to old shoulder injuries.
Upper body isn't that complicated desu, just have a full range horizontal press (deficit/ring pushups or super deep db bench) where you go to the absolute limit of your pec flexibility (at some point you'll get to the point where you literally cannot go any deeper due to the structure, this is what you want bc you'll have all the pec flexibility you'll ever need) some kind of external rotation movement (so you can internally rotate more by making the external rotators less tight, plus I think this helps with external rotation range a bit tooo due to making the external rotators stronger. Should be trained regardless to help with shoulder problems), and pullovers (helps with overhead shoulder mobility iirc). Obviously keep doing the dead hangs, they're also great for shoulder mobility.

Besides this I think whatever you're doing for upper body needs to be directly targeted (eg if you want to work on your shoulder mobility more you probably need to identify which muscle is stopping you and then work on stretching it), but there aren't a ton of areas to work on anyway so it isn't a huge deal.

>>69780343
Not OP
Yes, you should absolutely stretch. Flexibility is incredibly important, but just like with fitness most of the stretching gurus and retards you watch on youtube are fucking clueless and will overwork you or give you overly complex routines when simplicity is key.

The stretching redpill is:
STATIC stretching of a muscle (after warming up) for 4 sets of 30 seconds per day with a minute or so rest in between sets yields max flexibility gains. Anything else (dynamic, ballistic etc) is suboptimal and anything over this (2 minute sets etc) is superfluous and has diminishing returns.

>False, all 4 heads of the quad always work together and you can't even bias one
You can bias (NOT isolate) different parts of the quads, notably the VMO is much more active at both end ranges of motion (do a reverse stepup and you will literally only feel VMO, do lots of ATG squats and your VMO will be very sore the next day in comparison to the other muscles). However the rectus femoris is even more extreme because it cannot contribute much force in a squat due to it being a bi-articular muscle like the hamstrings, so it ends up acting isometrically for the most part. Sissy squats work the rectus femoris much better since the hips are held in extension allowing the rectus femoris to fully stretch and contract like the other quad muscles, which is why you get insane rec fem DOMS after doing lots of sissy squats.

My argument is that the bench press actually biases the chest less because leg drive makes the bottom portion easier. Essentially if you have a guy who fails around the mid range on bench, if you make him do a larsen press (assuming he knows how to use leg drive) he'll likely fail lower down closer to the chest. Now as we know the chest is most active in the bottom position on bench, but normal bench makes this part easier which is the opposite of what you want for chest growth. Larsen press solves this problem entirely (pausing makes it even better as you spend more time in the position where the chest is stretched)

>Partially true, it can work but it's TUT is extremely overrated
TUT is massively overrated I agree, however I think slow eccentrics and pauses are good for different reasons. They force you to use less weight which is good for hypertrophy since it reduces fatigue (since absolute load is an independent fatigue factor especially on axially loaded lifts), and it also promotes good technique as you can self-correct your technique more easily during the set. Pauses in particular are good because you get to spend more time in the lengthened position which is incredibly good for hypertrophy (Shortened position is ok too but stretch mediated hypertrophy exists so)

>abs should be trained hard and frequently
May I ask more detail on this? I see this often mentioned but not so much about: what exercises? How often? How long? How should you incorporate it within your usual workout?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69784281
>exercises
Weighted situps (weight behind head), hanging leg raises (toes to bar if you can), ab wheel rollouts, L-sit progression, dragon flags etc. Others are fine but these are my general recommendations as they're easily accessible and can be progressed without any problems.
>reps
Exercise dependent, but for most movements 8-20 reps is a good range to start with, and you can narrow it down from there if you want.
>sets
3-4 sets works well
>frequency
3-5x a week is alright but I have seen some people go as high as 7x with great results
>how to incorporate
Superset/giantset with other stuff works well, or if you're lazy like me you can do one set of abs inbetween each line of sets until you've performed enough sets. For example, instead of:

Bench 3x5-10
Pullups 3x5-10
OHP 3x8-12

you would do

Bench 3x5-10
Weighted situps 1xF
Pullups 3x5-10
Weighted situps 1xF
OHP 3x8-12
Weighted situps 1xF

Might seem a bit annoying however because most ab movements require very little equipment this actually works really well from my experience.

>>69785643
>What exercises will be enough to fully train forearms, beside reverse curls
Something for the flexors and extensors (there's also supination/pronation and radial/ulnar deviation but training these isn't worth it for most people unless you're injured/arm wrestler/grip specialist/forearm hypertrophy specialist etc). Behind the back barbell finger curls are great because they're very easy on the wrist tendons, however there are plenty of other exercises for the flexors you can try if you don't like those. For the extensors you can do reverse wrist roller or db/bb wrist extensions. Also there's stuff you can do for the finger extensors but that's more for injury prevention rather than hypertrophy.
>Why is larsen press better than regular bench press? Doesn't it engage more core to stabilize?
I think the core utilization is overstated on larsen press desu, it has never been a problem for me. It's better than bench for chest hypertrophy because leg drive on bench makes the bottom of the movement easier, which is the part of the movement where the chest is biased the most. Larsen press fixes that issue by removing leg drive.
>How long should eccentric and pauses last? 5s/1s? And what about negatives?
I don't use any numbers for these unless specified (typically 3 seconds for pauses, and I only use this on a few movements. I never specify the time for eccentrics). I'd say that a normal pause for me is around 1-2 seconds, as for the eccentric it depends on the exercise, just use whatever feels slow for that movement.

I'll list most of the lower body muscles of importance, lmk if there's anything else you want

Seated good mornings

ATG split squats, long lunge stretch, front split progression
>rectus femoris
Couch stretch, sissy squats, reverse nordics

Progressive ROM RDLs, jefferson curls, pancake progression, front split progression

Seated good mornings, weighted tailor's pose for reps

Middle splits progression, pancake progression
>gastroc
Straight-leg calf raises with an emphasis on the bottom position (keep knee locked, pull yourself deeper with your tibialis anterior, hold the bottom position for 3 seconds on every rep, 10 seconds after the last rep)
>soleus (also achilles tendon)
Seated calf raises, or KOT calf raises if you don't have a seated calf machine

I use a Fitbit charge 4. Was pretty cheap and easy to keep track of running, swimming, interval training, cycling, etc. Tracks my resting heart rate and sleep quality and as far as I can tell it’s pretty accurate.

I specifically looked for options without wifi or data enabled, because I don’t want that in my wrist 24/7.
Options seemed to be Garmin forerunner 45 for just basics, Polar vantage series for more advanced, some from Suunto peak series also “advanced” data, or Apple Watch if you turn off the mobile and wifi in settings and can additionally perform ECG apparently.

I still haven’t bought one because you’re looking at $500-$1,000 price range, I fee it’s worth it if it’s accurate, lasts a long time, and wear it every day. But I wonder how much I would actually use it, and how much benefit compared to a basic Fitbit or Garmin for just HR/variability/sleep time.
